data.text: <p>How do you get to Carnegie Hall?  Practice, practice, practice!  The surest way to fail at anything is to simply refuse to try.  What if you try and try and try and try, and still you fail? They're too busy living their own lives.  Why aren't you?Some of us don't have any audience for our websites, you know, while others don't have a website at all.  Yet somehow we still manage to be happy.What do you have to be happy about today?  Have you got a hangnail?  If not, then count that among your blessings.  Did you have to eat anybody today?  If not, then add that to the list.  Did anyone chew you out today?  If so, then just be glad they didn't swallow.  If they swallowed, then I'm sure things will come out alright in the end...What if you leave Purdue and find out Purdue was never the problem?  Remember--things can always be worse.  You could be in Fortville right now.</p>

data.name: Cameron
data.text: <p>And this is me breaking my own promise to myself not to any longer aknowledge posts that attack me, but I have to agree with Neal on this one.It's not very easy for us to continue to be friends with you when all you do is talk about how you'd much rather be spending time with your theatre friends than with us because they "respect" you so much more.I don't know what we did that makes you think that, but to the best of my knowledge I've never done anything that would suggest that I don't respect you. I mean, even recently, we went to your play and complimented it. I may have made some negative comments about the playwright and his pacing issues, but everything I said about the acting was very positive because the acting was very good. The only reason I made those comments about the script itself is because I wanted to share my honest opinion of the show with you because I respect you and I figured you'd want to hear what I actually thought about it. I read lines with you the other day, I've been raving about your work in 211 because, quite frankly, it's kicking the shit out of anything the rest of us are doing.I don't know what more you want from us. Maybe we aren't bending over backwards to compliment your website or laughing ourselves stupid over your techno remixes like your theatre friends do, but that doesn't mean that we don't respect you.I've never in my life busted my ass to keep someone as a friend who didn't want me around and I'm not about to start now. If you'd rather hang out with your theatre friends then fine, go ahead and do it. Clearly you understand and respect them a lot more than you understand and respect us.</p>

data.name: Lord Ontario
data.text: <p>I haven't invested a dime in video games for years (with the exception of KOTOR which is pretty awesome if you ignore the occasional, if not massive, visual errors it tends to get). I'd still rather play old RPGs on my PS1 than damn near anything that's out these days. I did have a short term addiction to Prince of Persia: The Warrior Within, but having beaten that in about 12 game hours there isn't much more to do with it.</p><p></p><p>11. Develop the story, develop the characters</p><p></p><p>Gameplay is important I'll grant you, but I've always played games (particularly RPGs, but even games like Grand Theft Auto) for the stories and the characters. A game is much more fulfilling if you've spent 40+ hours guiding the path of characters that you've become attached to on an emotional level. There aren't enough games out these days that try to deliver an original storyline with engaging characters. Even SquareEnix has been dropping the ball lately. I guess gaming companies haven't noticed that games like FF7 are still among the best sellers of all time.</p><p></p><p>12. Replayability</p><p></p><p>What good is a game that I can beat in a few days and never want to play again? Ubisoft doesn't care because I've already paid them (not really, but you get my point), but something makes me believe that they should. Give me good gameplay, a solid storyline, dynamic characters, and a game that I can play for 40+ hours and I'm set. It's even better if I can play that game again. Take a lesson from Square: make the plot so ridiculously complicated that you have to play through it 4 or 5 times before you even know what the hell is going on.</p><p></p><p>13. Graphics aren't worth shit if the game sucks</p><p></p><p>Believe it or not few people will buy a game just for the graphics. If the game isn't worth playing no amount of bump mapping is going to save it.</p><p></p><p>BUMP!!!</p>

data.text: <p>Excellent additions, my Lord.I'll just add another one that I forgot:</p><p> /</p><p> /14.  Let me quicksave, or count me out.</p><p>I'm just sick of games being ruined by the inability to quicksave.  Far Cry, Call of Duty 2, XIII, and Path of Neo are all based on autosave checkpoints.  Autosaves are fine for RPG's where you are less likely to have to fight a huge monster every single time you enter a new room, but action games absolutely require the ability to save the game anywhere.  Whithout it, when you get to a hard part, you have to replay the sequence leading up to it over and over and over until you finally beat the hard part.  In Far Cry, I was just so sick of replaying easy parts hundreds of times, I eventually just stopped playing it.</p><p></p><p>Let me save it wherever I want.  There is no reason not to.</p>

data.name: Peach Faygo Lover
data.text: <p>I think that video games are in the eye of the beholder. Sometimes you just like a game and you are not sure why. Example: Diablo is an awesome game, lots of gamers everywhere love to play it over and over again, but all those games taht come out that are just like Diablo but a different format, everyone hates. I mean the game is exactly the same its just a different storyline, yet no one likes them. Now yes, copying other games is a good way to get your game not played, but because Diablo was a first of its kind, everyone loved it and play it all the time. Now I like Path of Neo, keyword there is liked. The game had lots of bugs and the gameplay was pretty bad, also the gun fighting was not to my satisfaction. But when I installed the game the only thing I was really looking for was some descent hand to hand combat and it following the movie fairly well. I got that and so I was happy enough to get past the bugs and gameplay(which by the way the combat is really not that bad once you get used to it). Also it was kinda worth it to play the scene where you fight all the Smiths, and the surprise ending was neat. One last thing I'd like to say. Gameplay completly dwarves graphics, yet graphics enhance gameplay. If you have a solid storyline and gameplay, then you got a good game hands down, even if its text based. That is a thing that I would think developers would get from testing in alpha and beta.</p>

data.text: <p>To Aili,</p><p>You weren't there.  All you have is hearsay.  I understand that you are trying your best to advise Shauvon.  Given what you heard, you made the best decision you could.  I'll give you some more background, and you can tell me if your impression of the night changes any.  We don't drink that often.  Speaking for myself, I have been drunk 4 times in my life.</p><p>We were not using Shauvon for his room.  You might not realize this, but three people live in this room.  Two of them were drinking.</p><p>Chris doesn't normally give Shauvon crap about drinking at all.  What he meant (and couldn't say properly due to being drunk) is that if each weekend is worse exclusively because you don't drink, then you should look at the cause of each weekend being worse.</p><p>We don't drink because it's cool, we don't drink because that's the only way we can feel good, we don't drink alone, and we don't drink in the morning or dring the day.  We drink because it helps us loosen up after a long week.  It's how we stay balanced.  All work and no play, after all.  In other words, we're happy drunks.</p><p>We don't expect Shauvon to be designated puker-turner.  We don't expect him to do anything for or with us.  He's welcome to join us, he's welcome to drink with us, stay sober in our company, videotape us, or just be elsewhere.  Besides, he has never acted as designated puker-turner, so why should we expect it?  Shauvon just left when the room smelled bad.  I was the one who woke Mike and got him to clean up.</p><p>We expect only one thing from Shauvon: tell us when we're doing something he won't tolerate.  You might not realize this, but he never told us "guys, you're too loud" or "guys, the room smells bad" or "guys, can you do this somewhere else?"  We can go to Chris's room if necessary.  We could have done so last night, but the idea was never suggested.</p>

data.name: Barry
data.text: <p>What burns me about Friday night is that Shauvon went from silent acceptance to going straight to the RA if there was a problem.  I would have gladly listened to Shauivon's concerns, had he voiced them.  I would have even spoken for him if he didn't want to address our group alone.  This whole situation could have been averted.</p><p></p><p>I'm not saying that we should be allowed to drink in the room.  One of the points that Shauvon missed (and should have used) is that he is equally guilty as the rest of us if we are caught with alcohol in the room, unless he's the one turning us in.</p><p>I'm not saying that Shauvon's concerns about inebriation are without merit.  Alcoholism is a real problem for many people, and Shauvon had to watch others dear to him suffer because of that problem.</p><p>I'm not saying that Shauvon is responsible for our actions.  What kind of lunacy is that?  He wasn't even there.  How could he be responsible?  No one is responsible for the entire group.  Each person is responsible for his own actions.  At the same time, don't blame the group for the actions of an induvidual.  I'm just glad that Mike didn't choke and we didn't have to call an ambulance.</p><p></p><p>I rarely drink, and when I do, I watch how much I have.  I had my "way too much" time last Fall, and I vowed not to repeat that episode because it was embarassing for me and disgusting and oppressive for everyone else.  I know my limits, and I don't push it.  I can even enjoy myself without alcohol, but I like to occasionally get "buzzed" for a few hours.  Everything in moderation.</p><p></p><p>Enough of this.  I've been over this before.  Let's stop ranting on the website and sit down to discuss this like adults.  I find it immature that we can't face each other and say what needs to be said.  I suppose I'm no better, since I'm posting here, too.  This will be my last.  If any of you want to discuss this further, you know where to find me.</p>

The fact is, I only have to know one thing:  each of you are willing to break the law/campus rules to please yourselves.  It is illegal for anyone under the age of 21 to consume alcohol.  Period.  Many people make it to the age of 21 without breaking that law.  I don't know why so many people can't, but frankly, I don't care. data.name: Mom Again
data.text: <p>Interesting post, Peter, but I hardly think I've "picked my battle" on this one.  If I was gearing up for war, I'd be pulling the financial plug, threatening reprisals, and pushing Shauvon's emotional buttons.  Instead, I just made a few observations which he is free to accept or reject as he pleases.  My point was and is a general one, addressing the real definition of non-conformity.  (I agree with the post that urges more philosophical dialogue and less cringing angst.)  Here's the thing:  Shauvon has always insisted he hates having everyone make comments about his height, claiming that it makes him feel self-concious and freaky.  Then he turns around and does something to modify his appearance which basically adds about five more feet to his height--in other words, he now stands out more than ever.  I think, at the very least, he's forfeited the right to complain about people gawking or making comments about his appearance.  And while it's true that this new look is hardly a permanent alteration and Shauvon's appearance is, of course, his to do with what he likes, as someone who cares about him, I have to question whether there isn't some sort of self-destructive mechanism at work here.  He doesn't like being treated like a freak, so he makes himself more freakish.  Hmmmmm.  Of course, it's hard for me to relate to anyone who spends lots of time fussing over how they look, whether they're trying to look like a movie star or a freak.  Outward appearance is only a manifestation, and I think most people would be happier with themselves if they spent more time working on what's inside and less time primping in front of a mirror.  But that's just my opinion.  Oh, and my name isn't really Mom.  That, too, is only a manifestation.</p>

data.name: Shauvon
data.text: <p>I watched Live Free or Die Hard last night.  It was fantastic.  Let's take a look at my list, and see what made it, shall we?</p><p>"Yipee Kay Yay"  This token phrase made it in, of course.  I felt that used much better than the last two films, but it could never be as awesome as the first time.  This one was pretty obvious, so it's a bit of a freebie.a better ending than Die Hard with a Vengance  Live Free or Die Hard only got better and better as the movie went on, so the ending was the best part.  This was definitely a yes.John McClain has to fight a big German dude, who he ends up defeating using chains somehow. Lookout, though, because the German dude isn't actually dead.  This one wasn't perfect.  The bad guys weren't German, which was a disappointment.  John ends up fighting a small asian lady, which is just about the exact opposite of a big german dude.  However, it was extremely satisfying, and he did end up strangling her with elevator cables, which are pretty close to the chains he used in previous films.  Not perfect, but this one was fulfilled pretty well.McClain shows his technophobia.  Like most things from Die Hard 2, this seems to have never actually happened.  I'm content with going on like Die Hard 2 never happened.Bonnie Bodelia as Holly Gennero.  She never appeared, so IMDB was correct.  However, they did show a picture of her, and John's daughter played a major part, so the same "familial" themes were held together.Reginald VelJohnson and Samuel L. Jackson both need to reprise their roles. They reall manned down on this one.  Neither of these guys were even mentioned, and it was a shame.  What is Reginald VelJohnson doing now anyway?The enemy better be a group of German mercenary terrorists who all use MP5's for some reason.  As I said before, the bad guys were not German.  They were an odd mixture of american computer hackers and French mercenaries, a choice I will never understand.  They did not use MP5's, but rather went with much more realistic modified UMP rifles, with a very well placed MP7 showing up, as well.  McClain finally ditched his Baretta for a much lighter, more modern composite handgun.  No Steyer Augs, but that MP7 was way cooler, anyway.John McClain wears a white tank top.  McClain wore some sort of tan shirt, which pretty much started at the same color his shirts usually end at.  He still ended with a satisfying ammount of blood on him, though, so they held true to the McClain look.  I don't have a problem with Bruce Willis being completely bald this time around.  Willis, and by extension McClain, is becomming a very old dude.Numerous Christmas references.  Again, they totally manned down.  The movie didn't have a single Christmas reference."Winter Wonderland"  Granted, this was a stupid thing to wish for.  No matter how "Die Hard" this song is, nobody in their right mind would have it during the credits of an Independance Day film.  Still, it would have been nice.</p><p>There you have it.  The results weren't too bad at all, and I really enjoyed the movie.  I was not expecting much, but they really delivered.  This was very much a Die Hard movie, and it truly deserves the name.</p><p></p><p>And for those of you waiting for a similar list for the Transformers movie, I'm afraid I'll have to disappoint.  I've made a lot of effort to learn everything I can about the movie, so I don't have a lot of unrealistic expectation.  Even still, my expectation is pretty high.</p>

data.name: Bralf
data.text: <p>I don't agree with bashing a movie solely based on its director either, but I do agree with bashing poorly-made movies for being poorly made movies.I'm not sure whether it was the constant attempts at inane humor (oh! A giant robot is PEEING on that bad guy! ROBOT PEE IS HILARIOUS!), the total misunderstanding about what the movie is about (the Autobots aren't really introduced until about an hour and a half into the movie, and even then they're just introduced; we never get to know them whatsoever. Also, the MAIN VILLAIN isn't formally introduced until the final half hour), the completely jumbled action sequences (I had no idea what the hell was going on in the final city battle), the gaping plotholes (what ever happened to the Mountain Dew-machine Transformer? Why in God's name do the parents not believe in Transformers when the Transformers completely annihilated most of the downtown area?!), or the extended parts that involved no Transformers and nothing to further advance the plot (anything involving Jon Voight and/or the "hackers"), but I had a lot of ill-will in me after seeing Transformers.Luckily, the giant robots looked pretty awesome. And Shia LaBeouf was likable. Bumblebee was annoying and I can't imagine that anyone in the universe actually felt bad during his dramatic "torture" sequence.And while I don't blame Bay's past failures or successes on this film, I do have to blame Bay for making a crappy movie this time around. Personally, I love Bad Boys II. I know how sad that sounds.</p>

data.name: A No-Sided Man
data.text: <p>Well while we are talking about how people review movies. I really do not like it when someone sees something they don't like in a movie, then lets that feelings spill over into everything else in the movie. As humans, we do this all the time. I admit that sometimes I may not like the way a person wears their hair, so I assume I won't like them as a person at all. But you can't do this! For all I know that person is a rocket scientist or created the cell phone I'm using.</p><p></p><p>Back to Transformers, however, Yes the Autobots were not introduced until really far in. And yes alot of the movie didn't have to do with Transformers, but the human race. The producers had to make a movie that EVERYONE would like, not just the Transformer enthusiasts. And to do that they had to add other aspects. I thought the whole attack on the human race was a good touch. It made me feel more into the movie. (The only Transformers I ever watched was the Beast Wars series). And I also hated parts of the movie. Some of the scenes that were added could have been removed completley and would not have left and plot out.</p><p> </p><p>But I feel, Braft, that your spilling your bad feelings for some scenes over into the other parts of the movie. There are plenty of other movies that in the action scenes you can't follow anything. But I like that. The chaos is what makes you feel like your there and in the movie. (Which I think Bay did a godo job of, he did lots of angles that were shot up at the robots rather than looking down)  And if nothing you have to be impressed by the sheer CGI of Transforming robots. I mean I'm sure that it was one guys job to animate Optimus primps left index fingers and nothing else!</p><p> </p><p>Now I'm not saying you have to love the Movie Braft. Take a second, though, and remove the parts you didn't like of the movie and just watch the parts you liked. I bet you'll say wow that actually is an awesome movie.</p>

data.text: To the "fan" on Oct. 3--<br>I'm someone who many people have complained about being "too negative," but I'll never apologize for calling 'em like I see 'em, and neither should you.&nbsp; Sometimes it seems like we're all supposed to be divided into two camps:&nbsp; those "realists" who are Mr. Grumpy Negatives or those Pollyannas whoclaim all is sweetness and light while the world is crumbling.&nbsp; <br>But nothing is ever that black or white, of course.&nbsp; There are good things and bad things, and sometimes bad can be good and good can be bad.&nbsp; That's probably why these photos are so evocative--they compel us to reconsider those definitions.&nbsp; All that trash seems bad.&nbsp; But it is a result of our pleasant modern lifestyle, which is good.&nbsp; But such reckless disregard for the environment is bad.&nbsp; But the fact that someone noticed and we all want to do the "right thing" is good.&nbsp; But what is "the right thing"?&nbsp; And how do we do it?&nbsp; And what if we do the wrong thing by mistake?&nbsp; Worse yet, what if we do nothing?&nbsp; But who are we to <span style="font-style: italic;">do</span> something?&nbsp; Aren't there smarter people out there than we are, and shouldn't we let <span style="font-style: italic;">them</span> do what needs to be done?&nbsp; Besides, don't we all have plenty of other problems to take care of?&nbsp; I know I sure as hell do.<br>So you see, "fan," I don't think you should apologize for your posting.&nbsp; We're all in this together, and don't none of us know what's right or good or even worth mentioning.<br>Man, these pictures really make you think . . .<br>

data.text: <p>First of all, I want to say that the previous commenter was not me.&nbsp; I would not say "listen to your mom," because that would be the best way I can think of to make sure you would not listen to me.&nbsp; So, beware of imposters posing as your mother!&nbsp; (That's probably good advice for anyone.)</p><p>At any rate, I just recently defrosted my freezers and took the opportunity to inventory my food supplies.&nbsp; Since the data I derived dovetails nicely with your shopping trip, I thought you might be interested.</p><p>I currently have the following items I've grown and frozen:</p><p>60 pints peas; 102 pints green beans, 74 pints corn, 64 pints broccoli, 14 pints green peppers, 9 pints spinach, 20 quarts dried beans, 74 pints tomato sauce, 19 quarts tomato sauce, 30 pints soup, 24 quarts soup, 9 pints salsa, 1 quart salsa, 4 quarts tomato juice, 16 quarts grape and cherry juice, 3 quarts blueberries, 3 quarts strawberries, and 3 pints cranberries&nbsp; (the blueberries and cranberries are not from my garden, but I hope they soon will be).&nbsp; </p><p>In addition, I anticipate harvesting at least 3 bushels of potatoes, 3 bushels of sweet potatoes, and multiple more pints of celery, sauce, soup, and salsa.&nbsp; (Knock on wood with the potatoes--anything can still happen!)&nbsp; Keep in mind, too, I net at least 3 dozen eggs a week for six months of the year, giving me 78 dozen eggs, about half of which I sell.&nbsp; I am also not counting the multiple bushels of lettuce we harvest each year (gotta be at least 10 bushels!) and the quantities of herbs, hot peppers, etc.&nbsp; </p><p>While none of this is exactly cost-free because the seeds cost money and I've paid for tools, etc., and, of course, if you factor in my time the cost really goes up, but the point is that it costs nothing in terms of shipping or sales mark-up and it is as pure as food can be these days, being fertilized solely by poop from my chicken and goat friends.&nbsp; </p><p>Now, I'm not suggesting everyone should grow all their own food, but I do think that anyone who can grow ANYTHING, should do so whenever possible.&nbsp; After all, the element we haven't even factored into the cost/benefit analysis is the karmic cost of buying crap at the store.&nbsp; I have to believe that when you kill a life form with your own two hands and immediately consume it, you are racking up much less of a karmic debt than you do when you allow someone else to do your killing for you.&nbsp; I am confident that because I know my tomatoes are going to turn into me,&nbsp; I take greater care of them while they are alive and I slaughter them with greater respect than any commercial grower can muster.&nbsp; </p><p>Of course, that line of thinking goes way off in a completely different direction than a simple shopping trip . . .</p><p></p>

data.name: your mom
data.text: <p>Okay, so last night I was coming in from the goat pen, and as I was walking up the walkway to the porch, I saw Bartley lying in the grass there.&nbsp; As I walked by, he did not jump in front of me as he usually does, but rolled over and exposed his belly in a very alluring way, begging me to pet him.&nbsp; I thought, "Oh, he's finally turning cute!"&nbsp; And I petted him on the head, and scratched his chin and . . . then I thought, "Didn't you used to have more white fur?"&nbsp; I looked at him as I was petting him, while he was writhing around happily, and I was just SURE he used to have more white fur on his belly and his face.&nbsp; I looked at his face, and his eyes were the right color and his nose had that bump in it like it always has, so I thought, "Wow, I must be getting Alzheimery.&nbsp; I really thought he had more white on him."&nbsp; Then I turned around to go up the step AND THERE WAS BARTLEY!!!!!&nbsp; The cat I had been petting was someone else altogether, and Bartley was PISSED!</p><p>I ran to the door and yelled for Bob to come outside because something weird was going on.&nbsp; He came out and I showed him this new cat, who was a dead ringer for Bartley, except for the amount of white fur and the fact that the new guy still has all his original equipment.&nbsp; I was showing Bob how nice this new cat was by petting him when all of a sudden he attacked me, biting and scratching my arm, which put Bartley in motion, which put Not-Bartley in motion too.&nbsp; They both ended up in the driveway, rolling around like lions, howling and swishing their tails furiously.&nbsp; They ended up spending about ten minutes just howling at each other, during which time I'm pretty sure they were talking about me.&nbsp; I'm confident the new guy is Bartley's brother, who must live around the corner.&nbsp; He seemed very well-fed and well groomed, so I'm hoping I won't get rabies, but you never know.&nbsp; </p><p>I haven't seen either Bartley or not-Bartley today, but I've had a raccoon raiding the bird-feeder all day, in spite of the fact that it's full-on daylight and 150 degrees.</p><p>It's always exciting around here . . .</p><p></p>

data.title: Half Life 2
data.text:
<p>I suppose that I should comment on Half Life 2.  I have spent a good amout of time on the game, and I can tell you that it is one of the greatest games ever made.  It makes Doom 3 look pointless.  It plays like a feature film, and grips you like nothing I have ever seen, books, TV, movies, and theatre included.  It is probably the first game that actually convinces me that I am in a different place.  The graphics are so amazing, that I feel the world that I am in.  The story is extremely engaging, and the facial animations of the characters really makes me believe that they have their own emotions and feelings.  It is an amazing spectacle.  Half Life 2 is the dawning of a new age of computer games.  It gives you a glimpse at the limitless possibilities that computer games have.  Instead of simple diversions, games could be glorious works of art, comperable to any movie, and much more engaging.  It's a testament to the power that computers have.  Now, if you will excuse me, I will get back to my game.</p>
			<p></p>

data.title: Why
data.text:
<p>I had a thought. Actually I had a few thoughts. If you want to know why I've been really out of it lately, or you didn't know I was out of it and just wanted to know what was going through my mind, here's your answer.</p>

<p>Of course, you'll have to forgive me for answering your question with a question.</p>
			<p>Why am I here?</p>
			<p><em>Why am I here?</em></p>

<p>That's the question that occupies most of my mind lately. I don't mean it on a cosmic, 

meaning of life sort of level. Just, "what for?" Why am I working here? Why am I at Purdue? 

Why am I getting out of bed? I've been really struggling with the "what for" of 

everything. (bear with me, this does go somewhere)</p>

<p>The way I see it, life is a series of horrible events, strung together by periods of 

relative calm. Something terrible happens, either to me or the world around me. I deal with 

it, and it blows over ("events always have a way of working out"). I feel bad about the 

terrible thing that happened for a while (or I am otherwise affected by it). Time pushes 

those memories back, and they ultimately slip away. I calm down; I forget. Life moves on, and 

I'm left to wait for the next crisis.</p>

<p>It would be fine if those crisis points were balanced out, if every once in a while 

something really awesome happened to me. I don't have good things. I don't catch a break. All 

I get is neutral - periods of relative calm with which to catch my breath.</p>

<p>Here is an example. A couple weeks ago, I came down with a nasty stomach flu. I don't know 

what it was, and I don't care. All I care about is the fact that it made me throw up all 

night. If you know me at all, you should know that I have a pathological hatred of vomit. I 

hate talking about it. I hate hearing about it. There is absolutely nothing that I consider 

worse. I would rather lose a limb. <em>I would rather die.</em></p>

<p>Melodrama aside, the event crippled me. I was ready to come back to school (it was right 

at the end of the semester break), and have a great last semester. Instead, now I'm just 

living in fear of the next crisis. Every time I wake up in a cold sweat, because I heard my 

roommate go to the bathroom in the middle of the night, every time my stomach feels upset, 

every time I eat anything, I can't help but wonder if the time has come again. Did John catch 

something? Did I catch it, too? Will this bite be the one that makes me sick? It could happen 

any day, at absolutely any point, and there is absolutely nothing I can do to stop it. Worse 

still is the knowledge that it <em>will</em> happen again. It is inevitable.</p>

<p><em>Is that all I have to live for?</em></p>

<p>Some day, maybe soon, I will calm down. The memories won't be so fresh, and I'll be able 

to close my eyes without thinking about it. Some day I'll be able to go to sleep without 

wondering how soon I'll be woken up by nausea. On that day, when I finally forget, is when it 

will happen again.</p>

<p><em>Is that all I have to live for?</em></p>

<p>See, I don't know if I'll ever actually produce my pilot (in fact, I really doubt it). I 

don't think I'll ever fall in love. I don't know if I'll ever be able to build a computer 

that doesn't constantly crash. I don't know what kind of job I will be getting in a couple 

months when I graduate. I have no idea when, or <em>if</em> anything good will ever happen to 

me, but I do know that something bad <em>will</em>. It may not be vomiting. It could be my 

computer completely failing (or crashing while I'm working on something really important). It 

could be yet another person breaking my heart. It could be a Crazy Monkey show that I work 

hard on that turns out terribly. It could be one of a billion things that I couldn't possibly 

imagine. I don't know what bad thing will happen to me, but I do know that it will 

happen.</p>

<p><em>Is that all I have to live for?</em></p>

<p>If all I care about is just not vomiting (or whatever), why should I do anything? The more 

I'm in contact with people, the more I put myself at risk of catching something (or having my 

heart broken). If I don't care about getting a job (I'm really not sure that I am), when why 

do it? If I know all I will get out of class today is boredom, why should I go? If I don't 

think my pilot will ever be made, and I'm sure nobody will ever care (including myself), why 

should I work on it? Why not just sit around all day working on <a href="http://www.thecrazymonkeys.com/improv/">Stupid, Useless Crap</a>.</p>

<p>Here's you: "You dwell on the negative, Shauvon." That's the point I'm trying to make. 

When a crisis happens, we all dwell on the negative. We have to look at what's going wrong so 

we can do something to fix it. Then, when things are back to a status quo, we can forget it. 

We can fall back into our ignorance, and ignore how horrible the universe is. I can't do 

that. I refuse to ignore what's wrong. I refuse because I <em>need</em> to know what's wrong. 

I need to know <em>why</em>.</p>

<p>I could return to my life of contented ignorance, silently waiting for the next life-

altering crisis. I could work on my pilot. I could do my homework. I could, but then I would 

lose everything. I can't let go, because I need an answer.</p>

<p><em>Why am I here?</em></p>

<p>There has to be an answer to that question, because I <em>am</em> here. I'm out of bed. I 

went to class. I'm still thinking about ideas for my pilot. I ate something. I almost said 

something to a cute girl who sat next to me. Something is driving me, and I can't - <em>I 

can't</em> let go until I figure out what that is. I can't let go of this screaming 

desperation, this raging fear, until I have an answer. I can't embrace the ignorance again 

until I know why.</p>

<p>Ask yourselves, now. Why are you here? Put your hands down, that's rhetorical. I'm just 

saying, it's something you should know. Why do you get out of bed? Why do you risk getting 

sick every single moment of your lives? Maybe you don't need one (probably because you 

haven't had any crises lately). Maybe I'm the only person who needs a reason.</p>

<p><em>Why am I here?</em></p>
<p><em>Why not?</em></p>

<p>I'll leave you with the lyrics to a Nine Inch Nails song, <em>Getting Smaller</em> 

(because nobody understands an existential crisis like Trent Reznor). The song came up on my headphones, and it inspired me to come up with this whole diatribe.</p>

<pre>
Getting a little erratic here
And I don't know who to trust
I guess they got a way of reading my mind
I guess I gotta adjust
Got my arms they flip flop flip flop flip
Got my head on a spring
Well I thought I got you on my side
I haven't got fucking anything

I'm just a face in the crowd
Nothing to worry about
Not even trying to stand out
I'm getting smaller and smaller and smaller
And I have nothing to say
It's all been taken away
I just behave and obey
I'm afraid I am starting to fade away

I cannot see through the cracks
When I'm pressed up on the wall
I'm not looking to stand up real high
I'd be happy to crawl
I think I'm losing my grip
But I can still make a fist
You know I still got my one good arm
That I can beat...
I can beat myself up with!

I'm just a face in the crowd
Nothing to worry about
Not even trying to stand out
I'm getting smaller
And smaller and smaller
And I have nothing to say
Its all been taken away
I just behave and obey
I'm afraid I am starting to fade away

And for what it is worth
I really used to believe
That maybe there's some great thing
That we could achieve
And now I cant tell the difference
Don't know what to feel
Between what I've been trying so hard to see
And what appears to be real

Fading away
Fading away
Fading away
Fading away

My world is getting smaller everyday
My world is getting smaller everyday
(and that's okay)

My world is getting smaller everyday
My world is getting smaller everyday
(and that's okay)
</pre>

<p>Until next time.</p>

data.title: Love Hate
An open letter to Visa and Chase Bank
data.text:
<p>Dear Visa and Chase Bank,</p>

<p>I recently made a purchase from a website called Newegg.com. You probably aren't really 

aware they exist, but they probably receive hundreds if not thousands of charges (from Visa 

cards) every day for sweet electronic and computer bits. I tried to be one of those lucky 

people this morning.</p>

<p>You see, I moved recently, and so I have a new computer desk. The keyboard shelf I am now 

using is slightly smaller than I would like. Because I have too much money as it is, I decided 

to go ahead and buy a new, shorter keyboard to give my mouse more room to move about on my 

desk. Newegg.com, being the best place to buy computer bits, was the perfect place to shop for 

a keyboard.</p>

<p>The internet is supposed to be a magical world where anything is possible, and anything you 

could possibly dream of can be right at "your" fingertips (I put "your" in quotes because I 

realize that I'm currently speaking to a corporate entity with no real individual identity, 

plus "you" probably don't really have much desire for things like keyboards). As a young man 

in my early twenties, I have made hundreds, if not thousands, of purchases online for 

everything from sweet computer bits to train tickets to tonight's dinner. In fact, I have 

spent almost $8,000 on Newegg.com alone since June, 2004. I feel, as a young man in my early 

twenties, that the internet truly is "my oyster" and there is nothing I cannot accomplish 

using this glorious series of tubes. In short, I am highly competent with exactly this sort of 

task.</p>

<p>At least, that's what I thought until I got a Visa Debit card from Chase Bank.</p>

<p>I realize that the presence of nefarious ne'er-do-wells presents the necessity for 

increased security and "digital paranoia" (I just made that term up and I think it's pretty 

great). I acknowledge the concept that paying my bills online will forever be a painfully 

frustrating and bizarrely complicated process (I really don't care that much if someone wants 

to hack into my electricity account and pay my bill for me, but whatever). Paying bills is 

complicated, but it isn't impossible. I have to repeatedly check my email to recover passwords 

I only use once a month (at best), and answer security questions that I usually make fake 

answers to anyway. Eventually, the process is done, and my electricity remains on for another 

few weeks. Still, this process pales in comparison to the "Verified by Visa" process that you 

subject your customers to.</p>

<p>Upon placing my order today (on a website upon which I have placed many orders in the past 

without problem), I was directed to a page with a little box on it.</p>

<img src="/assets/images/visa/visa1.jpg" />

<p>I've seen the "Verified by Visa" process before, so my heart sank as I realized this order 

wasn't going to be as easy as I was hoping (or as easy as the bike helmet I just bought from 

Amazon (hopefully you've heard of them) with the exact same card, which simply required me to 

pick a billing and shipping address). I tried a few passwords, trying to remember the one I 

would have created for myself on that mysterious day that I supposedly created a "Verified by 

Visa" account. None of them worked. After a few failed attempts, you decided to stop letting 

me try.</p>

<img src="/assets/images/visa/visa2.jpg" />

<p>It might be worth noting at this point that I have, as a matter of fact, never actually 

created a "Verified by Visa" account. I know this because you eventually told me so. This 

makes it difficult to remember my password.</p>

<p>The (seemingly) handy link implying that I could generate a new password for myself served 

only to tell me that I didn't have an account, so I couldn't generate a new password. This is 

not the most helpful thing to read. It is, in fact, the type of thing that upon reading causes 

one's mind to turn quite quickly to thoughts of murder-suicide (preferably involving as many 

members of the Visa brain-trust as possible).</p>

<p>At this point, I knew that my only recourse was to call the phone number that was presented 

to me. All I wanted was my goddamn keyboard. I was not stealing anybody's identity, nor has 

anybody ever stolen mine, but I still had to be punished for it. Thank you, Visa, for having 

so much faith in your <em>own</em> system.</p>

<p>The automated compu-lady that greeted me on the phone offered no option to "just order my 

goddamn keyboard" so I picked a few choices that sounded like they would get me to a human 

being as quickly as possible. I had to enter the last four digits of my card number, so I 

entered the last four digits of the debit card I was trying to place the order on (the card 

that sparked this whole debacle in the first place). Compu-lady explained that I was incorrect 

(she obviously knew more about the card I was looking at than I did). I guess she didn't care 

about my card anymore, because she asked for my zip code. I gave her the zip code for my 

address here in Chicago (the address I promptly changed all of my banking information to). 

Again, I was wrong. This electro-broad obviously knew much more about me than I did. I tried 

my old, Lafayette, zip code, and it appeared to satisfy the compu-lady's (misinformed) 

obsession with me. She then asked me for the last four digits of my social security number, 

which I entered without problem. We had finally agreed on something. Mechano-girl put me on 

hold.</p> 

<p>I was, of course, repeatedly assured that the call would be monitored. I realize this is 

supposed to make me feel better, but it definitely does not. Why am I waiting for someone to 

pick up my call when you repeatedly tell me that someone else is already listening to me? I 

ended up on hold for over ten minutes, until someone (else) finally picked up.</p>

<p>"Welcome to Card Services, can I have your name, please?" the man asked.</p>

<p>"Shauvon McGill," I replied. Asking my name is a simple identity verification. Nobody else 

could possibly know that information.</p>

<p>"Okay, Mr. McGill, how can I help you today?"</p>

<p>"I am trying to make an online purchase and I guess I don't know my password," I told 

him.</p>

<p>"Okay, let me forward you to someone with online services.".</p>

<p>I was placed back on hold. At this point, if anybody was, in fact, monitoring my call, they 

were subjected to a slurry of foul language. I am deeply sorry for any trouble I caused to 

your spy department having to listen to my uncontrollable, raging frustration. I regret that 

it was generally un-creative, too, so it wouldn't even have been that interesting to listen 

to.</p>

<p>Finally, a woman picked up.</p>

<p>"Welcome to Card Services, can I have your name, please?" the woman asked. Note that 

absolutely nothing was different between the first and second agents, other than the fact that 

the second one was a woman and the first was a man. Apparently one could help me and the other 

could not (although it turns out that neither could actually help me).</p>

<p>"Shauvon McGill," I replied.</p>

<p>"Okay, Mr. McGill, how can I help you today?"</p>

<p>"I am trying to make an online purchase and I guess I don't know my password," I told her, 

through gritted teeth.</p>

<p>"Okay, I can help you with that. Let me just pull up your information." This surprised me. 

Up to this point, the only information she would have had was the (wrong) zip code that 

compu-lady got from me, the last four digits of my social security number, and my name, which 

I'm sure they would not be able to spell without thorough coaching.</p>

<p>"Is this for the card ending in XXXX?" She asked. It was not, actually.</p>

<p>"It's not, actually," I replied. Perhaps we had reached the source of the problem.</p>

<p>"Are you trying to use your Chase Visa Credit Card?" she asked.</p>

<p>"It's my Chase Visa Debit Card."</p>

<p>It turns out that I was talking to the "Credit Card Services" department, and that it was 

the entirely wrong department to talk to about my debit card. I told her that this was silly 

(which was not exactly the word I used, to be honest), because this was the number I was 

directed to call after using this very debit card. I would have to use my Chase Visa Credit 

Card to set up a "Verified by Visa" account, and the human-lady directed me to 

"verifiedbyvisa.com" where I could set up a new account (by the way, this would have been a 

great piece of advice to give me from the very beginning, instead of a "generate new password" 

link which didn't actually do anything). For some reason, the Verified by Visa website 

wouldn't open, because nothing ever works right when I try to use it, so I couldn't set up a 

new account. The human-lady offered to redirect me to technical support, and I told her I just 

wanted my goddamn keyboard.</p>

<p>I was so frustrated at this point that I told the agent I was just going to forget the 

whole thing and do something else (such as buy a keyboard from Amazon). I apologized for the 

language I used and acknowledged that none of this was her fault, and then I hung up. I clicked 

the "cancel" link on the "Verified by Visa" password box, and I was redirected back to 

Newegg.com's checkout process. Then I was rather surprised.</p>

<p>I was surprised, you see, because I was looking at an order confirmation. I had to check my 

order history to be sure, and make sure I had gotten a confirmation email from Newegg, but it 

was true. My order was completed successfully. In spite of not being "Verified by Visa," it 

was successfully charged anyway. "Oh," I thought, "well, whatever." I had finally ordered my 

goddamn keyboard.</p>

<p>I hope at this point you have noticed some glaring problems with your entire process, but 

just to be clear, let's go over a few points. First, you sent me on a perilous quest to have 

control of my own money based on a credit card that I wasn't even using. You see, I wanted to 

just order this goddamn keyboard with the money in my checking account, which is curiously why 

I decided to use my debit card instead of my credit card. You decided that I was using my 

credit card anyway. This is why I didn't actually have an account, and I was therefore unable 

to actually "verify by Visa." I would hope, as one of the most powerful money laundering 

corporations in the world, you understand the difference between "credit" and "debit." Perhaps 

you should take a look at an economics textbook (which, incidentally, Amazon recommends that I 

buy because I bought one once).</p>

<p>Second, the phone number you told me to call was just a general account information number, 

not in any way designed to assist me with "Verified by Visa." I was forced to have someone 

manually redirect me to where I needed to go (which was not actually where I needed to go). 

Perhaps if you had electro-broad simply explain that anyone having difficulty with "Verified 

by Visa" was probably best off just placing their order through paypal (or switching to Master 

Card), you could alleviate much of your call congestion.</p>

<p>Third, even though you seem to be in pretty serious "cahoots" with Chase bank, you don't 

seem to have gotten the memo that I have changed my billing address zip code. Secure systems 

don't work if you don't actually update them when I change my information. It isn't identity 

theft if I know more about my life than you do, Visa.</p>

<p>Finally, probably the biggest problem with this system is the fact that after I failed to 

log in and was locked out of my (non-existent) "verified by Visa" account, the order still 

went through without a problem. If I were, in fact, some nefarious ne'er-do-well who had 

stolen some poor dude's debit (not credit) card so that I could buy keyboards on the internet, 

I would have easily accomplished that goal, and I wouldn't even have needed to verify <em>My 

Own Name</em> to do so.</p>

<p>Visa and Chase Bank, you obviously are trying to ensure my safety online. I understand 

that. I appreciate your efforts, but I also laugh at them. You are, frankly, doing a terrible 

job. I suspect that this is part of a larger conspiracy to convince people to continue to shop 

in real stores instead of buying goods online, and that idea scares me. I feel more secure 

with my Facebook account than I do with my debit card. This is simply a travesty, and it is so 

much a travesty that I felt the necessity to write this open letter to you immediately. Put 

simply, you are ruining the world. Please make an effort to allow me to control where my own 

money goes, and don't punish me for trying to do so. I assure you, I know what I'm doing, and 

if I can't figure it out, someone who isn't between the ages of 18 and 25 will never have a 

chance. After this, I completely understand how our economy has gotten to where it is. Visa 

and Chase Bank, you are to blame. I wish I didn't despise the way our society works just a 

little bit more each and every time I make a purchase.</p>

<p>I just wanted a goddamn keyboard.</p>

<p>Sincerely,</p>

<p>Shauvon G. (I know my middle initial, too!) McGill, Consumer</p>

data.title: The Three Thieves
data.text: Three thieves were running from the police, and they ran into a warehouse to escape from them. The thieves each jumped into large bags to hide. The policemen searched through the warehouse and found the bags, not knowing what they were. They kicked the first bag, and the theif inside says, "bark, bark." They move on to the next bag, and after a firm kick, it says, "mew, mew." Finally, the policemen get to the third bag, kick it, and it says, "potatoes, potatoes!"

data.title: J. Alfred Prufrock
data.text:
<p>A poem by T. S. Eliot</p>
			<br>Let us go then, you and I,
	<br>When the evening is spread out against the sky
	<br>Like a patient etherised upon a table;
	<br>Let us go, through certain half-deserted streets,
	<br>The muttering retreats
	<br>Of restless nights in one-night cheap hotels
	<br>And sawdust restaurants with oyster-shells:
	<br>Streets that follow like a tedious argument
	<br>Of insidious intent
	<br>To lead you to an overwhelming question...
	<br>Oh, do not ask, "What is it?"
	<br>Let us go and make our visit.
	<br><br>
	<br>In the room the women come and go
	<br>Talking of Michelangelo.
	<br><br>

	<br>The yellow fog that rubs its back upon the window-panes,
	<br>The yellow smoke that rubs its muzzle on the window-panes,
	<br>Licked its tongue into the corners of the evening
	<br>Lingered upon the pools that stand in drains,
	<br>Let fall upon its back the soot that falls from chimneys,
	<br>Slipped by the terrace, made a sudden leap,
	<br>And seeing that it was a soft October night,
	<br>Curled once about the house, and fell asleep.
	<br>And indeed there will be time
	<br>For the yellow smoke that slides along the street
	<br>Rubbing its back upon the window-panes;
	<br>There will be time, there will be time
	<br>To prepare a face to meet the faces that you meet;
	<br>There will be time to murder and create,
	<br>And time for all the works and days of hands
	<br>That lift and drop a question on your plate,
	<br>Time for you and time for me,
	<br>And time yet for a hundred indecisions,
	<br>And for a hundred visions and revisions,
	<br>Before the taking of a toast and tea.
	<br><br>

	<br>In the room the women come and go
	<br>Talking of Michelangelo.
	<br><br>
	<br>And indeed there will be time
	<br>To wonder, "Do I dare?" and, "Do I dare?"
	<br>Time to turn back and descend the stair,
	<br>With a bald spot in the middle of my hair.
	<br>(They will say: "How his hair is growing thin!")
	<br>My morning coat, my collar mounting firmly to the chin,
	<br>My necktie rich and modest, but asserted by a simple pin.
	<br>(They will say: "But how his arms and legs are thin!")
	<br>Do I dare
	<br>Disturb the universe?
	<br>In a minute there is time
	<br>For decisions and revisions which a minute will reverse.
	<br><br>

	<br>For I have known them all already, known them all.
	<br>Have known the evenings, mornings, afternoons,
	<br>I have measured out my life with coffee spoons;
	<br>I know the voices dying with a dying fall
	<br>Beneath the music from a farther room.
	<br>So how should I presume?
	<br><br>
	<br>And I have known the eyes already, known them all.
	<br>The eyes that fix you in a formulated phrase,
	<br>And when I am formulated, sprawling on a pin,
	<br>When I am pinned and wriggling on the wall,
	<br>Then how should I begin
	<br>To spit out all the butt-ends of my days and ways?
	<br>And how should I presume?
	<br><br>

	<br>And I have known the arms already, known them all.
	<br>Arms that are braceleted and white and bare
	<br>(But in the lamplight, downed with light brown hair!)
	<br>Is it perfume from a dress
	<br>That makes me so digress?
	<br>Arms that lie along a table, or wrap about a shawl.
	<br>And should I then presume?
	<br>And how should I begin?
	<br><br>
	<br>Shall I say, I have gone at dusk through narrow streets
	<br>And watched the smoke that rises from the pipes
	<br>Of lonely men in shirt-sleeves, leaning out of windows?
	<br><br>
	<br>I should have been a pair of ragged claws
	<br>Scuttling across the floors of silent seas.
	<br><br>

	<br>And the afternoon, the evening, sleeps so peacefully!
	<br>Smoothed by long fingers,
	<br>Asleep ... tired ... or it malingers,
	<br>Stretched on the floor, here beside you and me.
	<br>Should I, after tea and cakes and ices,
	<br>Have the strength to force the moment to its crisis?
	<br>But though I have wept and fasted, wept and prayed,
	<br>Though I have seen my head (grown slightly bald) brought in
	<br>upon a platter,
	<br>I am no prophet-and here's no great matter;
	<br>I have seen the moment of my greatness flicker,
	<br>And I have seen the eternal Footman hold my coat, and snicker,
	<br>And in short, I was afraid.
	<br><br>
	<br>And would it have been worth it, after all,
	<br>After the cups, the marmalade, the tea,
	<br>Among the porcelain, among some talk of you and me,
	<br>Would it have been worth while,
	<br>To have bitten off the matter with a smile,
	<br>To have squeezed the universe into a ball
	<br>To roll it towards some overwhelming question,
	<br>To say: "I am Lazarus, come from the dead,
	<br>Come back to tell you all, I shall tell you all!"
	<br>If one, settling a pillow by her head,
	<br>Should say: "That is not what I meant at all.
	<br>That is not it, at all."
	<br><br>

	<br>And would it have been worth it, after all,
	<br>Would it have been worth while,
	<br>After the sunsets and the dooryards and the sprinkled streets,
	<br>After the novels, after the teacups, after the skirts that trail along
	<br>the floor.
	<br>And this, and so much more?
	<br>It is impossible to say just what I mean!
	<br>But as if a magic lantern threw the nerves in patterns on a screen:
	<br>Would it have been worth while
	<br>If one, settling a pillow or throwing off a shawl,
	<br>And turning toward the window, should say:
	<br>"That is not it at all,
	<br>That is not what I meant, at all."
	<br><br>
	<br>No! I am not Prince Hamlet, nor was meant to be;
	<br>Am an attendant lord, one that will do
	<br>To swell a progress, start a scene or two,
	<br>Advise the prince; no doubt, an easy tool
	<br>Deferential, glad to be of use,
	<br>Politic, cautious, and meticulous;
	<br>Full of high sentence, but a bit obtuse;
	<br>At times, indeed, almost ridiculous.
	<br>Almost, at times, the Fool.
	<br><br>

	<br>I grow old ... I grow old ...
	<br>I shall wear the bottoms of my trousers rolled.
	<br><br>
	<br>Shall I part my hair behind? Do I dare to eat a peach?
	<br>I shall wear white flannel trousers, and walk upon the beach.
	<br>I have heard the mermaids singing, each to each.
	<br><br>
	<br>I do not think that they will sing to me.
	<br><br>
	<br>I have seen them riding seaward on the waves
	<br>Combing the white hair of the waves blown back
	<br>When the wind blows the water white and black.
	<br><br>

	<br>We have lingered in the chambers of the sea
	<br>By sea-girls wreathed with seaweed red and brown
	<br>Till human voices wake us, and we drown.

data.title: Untitled
data.text:
<p>A poem by Bill Watterson</p>
		<br>I made a big decision a little while ago.
	<br />I don't remember what it was, which prob'ly goes to show
	<br />That Many times a simple choice can prove to be essential
	<br />Even though it often might appear inconsequential.
	<br /><br />
	<br />I must have been distracted when I left my home because
	<br />Left or right I'm sure I went. (I wonder which it was!)
	<br />Anyway, I never veered: I walked in that direction
	<br />Utterly absorbed, it seems, in quiet introspection.
	<br /><br />
	<br />For no reason I can think of, I've wandered far astray.
	<br />And that is how I got to where I find myself today.
	<br /><hr width='10%' style='margin-left: 20px' />
	<br />Explorers are we, intrepid and bold,
	<br />Out in the wild, amongst wonders untold.
	<br />Equipped with our wits, a map, and a snack,
	<br />We're searching for fun and we're on the right track!
	<br /><hr width='10%' style='margin-left: 20px' />
	<br />My mother has eyes in the back of her head!
	<br />I don't quite believe it, but that's what she said.
	<br />She explained that she'd been so uniquely endowed
	<br />To catch me when I did Things Not Allowed.
	<br />I think she must also have eyes on her rear.
	<br />I've noticed her hindsight is unusually clear.
	<br /><hr width='10%' style='margin-left: 20px' />
	<br />At night my mind does not much care
	<br />If what it thinks is here or there.
	<br />It tells me stories it invents
	<br />And makes up things that don't make sense.
	<br />I don't know why it does this stuff.
	<br />The real world seems quite weird enough.
	<br /><hr width='10%' style='margin-left: 20px' />
	<br />What if my bones were in a museum,
	<br />Where aliens paid good money to see 'em?
	<br />And suppose that they'd put me together all wrong,
	<br />Sticking bones on to bones where they didn't belong!
	<br /><br />
	<br />Imagine phalanges, pelvis, and spine
	<br />Welded to mandibles that once had been mine!
	<br />Which each misassemblage, the error compounded,
	<br />The aliens would draw back in terror, astounded!
	<br /><br />
	<br />Their textbooks would show me in grim illustration,
	<br />The most hideous thing ever seen in creation!
	<br />The museum would commission a model in plaster
	<br />Of ME, to be called, "Evolution's Disaster"!
	<br /><br />
	<br />And paleontologists there would debate
	<br />Dozens of theories to help postulate
	<br />How man survived for those thousands of years
	<br />With teeth-covered arms growing out of his ears!
	<br /><br />
	<br />Oh, I hope that I'm never in such manner displayed,
	<br />No matter HOW much to see me the aliens paid.
	<br /><hr width='10%' style='margin-left: 20px' />
	<br />I did not want to go with them.
	<br />Alas, I had no choice.
	<br />This was made quite clear to me
	<br />In threat'ning tones of voice.
	<br /><br />
	<br />I protested mightily
	<br />And scrambled 'cross the floor.
	<br />But though I grabbed the furniture,
	<br />They dragged me out the door.
	<br /><br />
	<br />In the car, I screamed and moaned.
	<br />I cried my red eyes dry.
	<br />The window down, I yelled for help
	<br />To people who passed by.
	<br /><br />
	<br />Mom and Dad can make the rules
	<br />And certain things forbid,
	<br />But I can make them wish that they
	<br />Had never had a kid.
	<br /><hr width='10%' style='margin-left: 20px' />
	<br />Now I'm in bed,
	<br />The sheets pulled to my head.
	<br />My tiger is here making Zs.
	<br />He's furry and hot.
	<br />He takes up a lot
	<br />Of the bed and he's hogging the breeze.

data.title: Michigan Avenue
data.text:
<p>Not long after I moved to Chicago, I took a trip to Michigan Avenue (the Magnificent Mile) to take some pictures. It was still very exciting to live in Chicago, and it was fun to go to Michigan Avenue as a resident instead of a tourist. This place was always such a exotic location - a place I only went as part of a big special trip. Of course, whenever I came to Chicago, I was obsessed with looking like I belonged here. I didn't want to look like I was excited about anything or like I was seeing things for the first time. I did not want anybody to look at me and say, "there's total tourist." If you had told me when I was seventeen that I would live in Chicago, and - in fact - work right on Michigan Avenue (I had a contract in the Tribune Building for the first three months in 2012), I never would have believed you. Yet here I was in August, 2009, resident of Chicago, walking up and down Michigan Avenue. All I wanted to do was gawk and the cool buildings and take pictures - like a total tourist.</p>

data.title: How to Website
data.text:
<p>Have you always wanted a super cool website? Do you want to enter the exciting and unfathomably vast and lonely sea of websites and mostly garbage that is the Internet? Do you look at Me with scornful envy in your eyes, cursing and damning and cursing again at my ability to website a whole bunch of times when you could never hope to website? Well, my friend, the time has come to learn that it isn&acirc;&#128;&#153;t that hard to website - in fact, even you can do it! Over the next few posts, I&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll show you every step in the process of putting together and deploying a fully functional blog-based website! No longer will you be held back by your technical ignorance. In a few days, the only thing that will be able to stop you from having your own website is your inability to come up with interesting things to write about.

I am a professional websiteman, by trade - that is, I specialize in doing websites. Aside from DenyConformity.com (pretty much the best website), I&acirc;&#128;&#153;ve made quite a few others for friends, clients, companies, or myself. The hard part is designing and putting together a unique and interesting site layout, and for the most part that&acirc;&#128;&#153;s what I get paid a bunch of money for. It&acirc;&#128;&#153;s actually really easy to website, though, if you don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t mind using pre-made components. Okay, so it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s still pretty complicated, but as long as you follow the proper procedure, for about $100 a year you can have your very own website on your own unique domain name. This is all assuming, of course, that you&acirc;&#128;&#153;ve thought about what you actually want a website for, and have a clear goal in mind for what you want to do with it. I&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll show you the &acirc;&#128;&#156;how&acirc;&#128;&#157; but you have to bring the &acirc;&#128;&#156;why.&acirc;&#128;&#157;

I should mention that this whole guide is about Windows 7. This is all equally easy in Mac OS or Windows Vista, but I don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t have those so I can&acirc;&#128;&#153;t really get screenshots of them.

Part 1: Get Ready to Website

You could make things easier for yourself by just buying a hosting plan and doing everything there, but that&acirc;&#128;&#153;s not the right way to do it. You could end up taking days or weeks (or years) setting up the site, and in the meantime your janky-assed &acirc;&#128;&#156;work in progress&acirc;&#128;&#157; is fully public for the world to see. Sure, you can set it up to show a &acirc;&#128;&#156;coming soon&acirc;&#128;&#157; page and block search engines until you get it finished, but it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s way easier to just set the site up on your computer and then deploy it to your web space.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/01.jpg]
That Bluehost.com lady is really ready to help you website.

You probably should go ahead and buy your hosting plan right away, though. The sooner you register your domain name, the better, so that nobody else steals it from you. Also, it can take up to a few days for your new domain name to start working, so you might as well do it now. I won&acirc;&#128;&#153;t get into explaining what a web host is, but basically you need a little hard drive to put your website on which is visible to the Internet. There are many companies you can use, and most of them are very similar - just make sure your plan includes a MySQL database (you&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll be hard pressed to find one that doesn&acirc;&#128;&#153;t) and email addresses if you want your own email addresses. DenyConformity.com is hosted on Bluehost, and I&acirc;&#128;&#153;m very pleased with them. Whatever you do, avoid GoDaddy or Startlogic.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/0-1.jpg]
Damn, pin15.com is not available.

The process is different based on who you use, but it should be pretty simple. Just find the &acirc;&#128;&#156;sign up now&acirc;&#128;&#157; button and fill in the blanks. Most hosting companies will give you a domain name with your plan, and they will help you register it (and make sure it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s available). There is really a whole industry around picking a domain name, but don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t overthink it. If you&acirc;&#128;&#153;re setting up a personal website, just use your name (dot com). If you have a small business, use the company name - or some variation of it (dot com). You can use a .org or .net address if you absolutely have to, but you should stick with a .com. Also try to avoid dashes, underscores, or other awkward characters; it can be harder to tell people &acirc;&#128;&#156;something dash something dot com&acirc;&#128;&#157; than just &acirc;&#128;&#156;something something dot com.&acirc;&#128;&#157; 

[/assets/images/how_to_website/0-2.jpg]
What a waste of a perfectly good domain name!

If your preferred domain isn&acirc;&#128;&#153;t available, but it obviously isn&acirc;&#128;&#153;t a real site (like the picture above), it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s probably held by a cybersquatter. These ne'erdowells are the scum of the Internet, but there isn&acirc;&#128;&#153;t much you can do about them. Sometimes GoDaddy can help you buy these domains, usually because they&acirc;&#128;&#153;re the ones illegally holding them. If all else fails, you can do a WHOIS lookup on the domain to get the contact info for the people who registered the domain. Don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t expect much luck, because usually these are very undesirable types, but you never know.

Anyway, once you get the hosting all squared away, they&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll send you an email with a bunch of technical gobbledygook in it about your new website. Make sure you archive, print out, or otherwise save that info in a place. Don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t worry about it for now, but know that it is important. Now you just have to wait patiently for Magic to Happen so that your new website becomes an Internet (it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s all very technical).

Don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t just sit back, though, because you still have a lot of work to do! We&acirc;&#128;&#153;re going to create your website right there on your computer, which means we have to turn your computer into a sort of makeshift Internet. Unfurrow that brow; it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s actually pretty easy. 

[/assets/images/how_to_website/1.jpg]
Open up the Start Menu, and hit the &acirc;&#128;&#156;Control Panel&acirc;&#128;&#157; button. If you don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t have a &acirc;&#128;&#156;Control Panel&acirc;&#128;&#157; button, then you&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll have to get to the control panel a different way. Try just typing &acirc;&#128;&#156;Control Panel&acirc;&#128;&#157; in the search box. Just get to the Control Panel, and then meet me at the next step.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/2.jpg]
Here&acirc;&#128;&#153;s the default Control Panel view. Click on &acirc;&#128;&#156;Uninstall a program&acirc;&#128;&#157; under &acirc;&#128;&#156;Programs&acirc;&#128;&#157; Don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t worry about your computer being powerful enough to Internet. If it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s running Windows 7 okay, it will be able to Internet okay, at least as much as we&acirc;&#128;&#153;re going to ask it to, which won&acirc;&#128;&#153;t be much. It won&acirc;&#128;&#153;t have to Internet terribly hard.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/3.jpg]
Look, stop worrying about how many C++ Redistributables I have, and just click &acirc;&#128;&#156;Turn Windows features on or off.&acirc;&#128;&#157; Click &acirc;&#128;&#156;allow&acirc;&#128;&#157; or whatever if Windows gives you guff about wanting to use your computer.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/4.jpg]
Back in the day you would disable some of these things to save precious Megabytes on your hard drive for sweet games, but with today&acirc;&#128;&#153;s multifoliate Jiggabytes, you can use your computer for years without ever needing to remove Solitaire. Anyway, we want to click the little box next to &acirc;&#128;&#156;Internet Information Services.&acirc;&#128;&#157; That&acirc;&#128;&#153;s what turns your computer into an Internet! Note: I&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll be referring to Internet Information Services as IIS from now on.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/5.jpg]
This is what should happen when you click the box. It automatically selects the most common options, which includes &acirc;&#128;&#156;Web Management Tools&acirc;&#128;&#157; and &acirc;&#128;&#156;World Wide Web Services.&acirc;&#128;&#157; Also, under &acirc;&#128;&#156;World Wide Web Services&acirc;&#128;&#157; open &acirc;&#128;&#156;Application Development Features&acirc;&#128;&#157; and make sure &acirc;&#128;&#156;CGI&acirc;&#128;&#157; is selected.  If for some reason you already have IIS installed, make sure you have subitems installed like you see in the picture above so you can properly website when we get to steps down the road.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/6.jpg]
After a bit of a wait (but not long enough for me to get a screenshot, apparently), you&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll have to restart your computer. Make sure you save anything you&acirc;&#128;&#153;re working on, like for example a post on your blog that you&acirc;&#128;&#153;ve been working on for like an hour but forgot to save. You don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t want to have to start from the freaking beginning again even though the second time you write it you aren&acirc;&#128;&#153;t anywhere near as funny as the first time.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/7.jpg]
When your computer comes back up, it won&acirc;&#128;&#153;t look any different - and it won&acirc;&#128;&#153;t behave any differently either (it shouldn&acirc;&#128;&#153;t, at least). However, your computer is now basically an Internet. Now you have to do some configuration to get a website set up.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/8.jpg]
Type &acirc;&#128;&#156;Administrative Tools&acirc;&#128;&#157; into your Start Menu, and find the Administrative Tools. It might show up before you finish typing the whole thing, so it will save you some precious finger movements.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/9.jpg]
This is where you can do some serious Administration on your computer. For now, you want &acirc;&#128;&#156;Computer Management&acirc;&#128;&#157;

[/assets/images/how_to_website/10.jpg]
Expand &acirc;&#128;&#156;Services and Applications&acirc;&#128;&#157; and pick &acirc;&#128;&#156;Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager&acirc;&#128;&#157; from the list on the left. This is where you tell your computer how to deal with being an Internet. There&acirc;&#128;&#153;s a ton to the IIS manager, but we won&acirc;&#128;&#153;t need to mess with most of it.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/11.jpg]
You should see this &acirc;&#128;&#156;Connections&acirc;&#128;&#157; section, on the left side of the Management Console. You&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll see your computer&acirc;&#128;&#153;s name (that&acirc;&#128;&#153;s your computer&acirc;&#128;&#153;s name, FYI - mine is called SEPTEM for some reason). Expand that and also expand &acirc;&#128;&#156;Sites&acirc;&#128;&#157; and you should see &acirc;&#128;&#156;Default Web Site.&acirc;&#128;&#157; Click on it. If you don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t have a &acirc;&#128;&#156;Default Web Site,&acirc;&#128;&#157; something has gone wrong. Try removing and reinstalling IIS. I brought you here to show you that your computer is running a tiny little Internet. You&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll need to get back here a few times over the rest of the process, so it&acirc;&#128;&#153;s good to know how to get to the IIS console and your Default Site.

[/assets/images/how_to_website/12.jpg]
Open a web browser (any will do), and type &acirc;&#128;&#156;localhost&acirc;&#128;&#157; into the address bar. If you see the IIS7 logo, you&acirc;&#128;&#153;re in business! You&acirc;&#128;&#153;re looking at your very own website running right there on your computer. Don&acirc;&#128;&#153;t worry, it only exists on your computer, and only you can get there. When you go to &acirc;&#128;&#156;localhost&acirc;&#128;&#157; you&acirc;&#128;&#153;re telling the browser to look for a web server on the local computer. You could also go to http://127.0.0.1, since that&acirc;&#128;&#153;s a computer&acirc;&#128;&#153;s internal IP address (by default, anyway). Anyway, if you got that lovely IIS welcome screen, you&acirc;&#128;&#153;ve successfully completed the first part of the process.

So today we (maybe) bought a new hosting plan somewhere and got the ball rolling on getting some real webspace, then we set up IIS and took a look at a tiny little Internet running right there inside your computer. Next time we&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll look at setting up and configuring a new local Web Site, and we&acirc;&#128;&#153;ll install and configure a MySQL database.</p>
